message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding, are suggestive of endometrial hyperplasia. The fact that the transvaginal ultrasound revealed an endometrial thickness of 4 mm supports this diagnosis, as endometrial hyperplasia is often associated with increased endometrial thickness. Endometrial carcinoma is a possibility but is less likely given the patient's age and negative Pap smear and HPV test. Uterine adenomyosis and endometrial polyps may also cause heavy bleeding, but they would typically present with other symptoms such as pelvic pain or discomfort, which the patient did not report.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing abnormal uterine bleeding, and among the options, only endometrial hyperplasia can cause heavy and prolonged bleeding without any other noticeable symptoms. The transvaginal ultrasound showed a normal endometrial thickness ruling out endometrial carcinoma, adenomyosis or polyps.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding, along with a normal transvaginal ultrasound but without any malignancies or masses suggest the most likely cause is endometrial hyperplasia. Endometrial polyps and adenomyosis can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, but they would likely be seen on the ultrasound. Endometrial carcinoma typically presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding or spotting, not just heavy periods.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest endometrial hyperplasia, which is an abnormal proliferation of the endometrial lining. This condition can cause heavy and prolonged periods. The normal endometrial thickness is <5 mm, and more than 5 mm indicates a risk of endometrial hyperplasia. The transvaginal ultrasound result of 4 mm thickness suggests that endometrial carcinoma, adenomyosis, and endometrial polyp are less likely causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including longer and heavier menstrual cycles and a thickened endometrial lining, suggest endometrial hyperplasia. Endometrial carcinoma is also a possibility, but the patient’s negative Pap smear and HPV test 5 years ago make it less likely. Uterine adenomyosis and endometrial polyps may cause abnormal bleeding, but they would not necessarily cause changes in the length and heaviness of menstrual cycles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an increased menstrual flow and duration, and an ultrasound showed a thin endometrial lining, which is less likely associated with endometrial carcinoma or adenomyosis. Endometrial polyp is a possible cause, but the most likely condition is endometrial hyperplasia, which can cause excessive menstrual bleeding and is associated with an increased risk for endometrial carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, along with the ultrasound findings of thickened endometrium, suggest endometrial hyperplasia. Endometrial carcinoma typically presents with postmenopausal bleeding, and uterine adenomyosis and endometrial polyps usually present with dysmenorrhea and irregular menstrual bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding suggest endometrial hyperplasia. The negative physical and pelvic examination, as well as the transvaginal ultrasound with a thin endometrial lining, make endometrial carcinoma and uterine adenomyosis less likely. Endometrial polyps may cause abnormal bleeding, but the ultrasound did not show any evidence of polyps.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding, but no abdominal or pelvic discomfort. The transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial thickness within the normal range, ruling out endometrial carcinoma. Adenomyosis would present with a tender uterus on palpation and transvaginal ultrasound will show thickened and heterogeneous uterine walls. An endometrial polyp is also possible, but endometrial hyperplasia is a more likely cause with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has longer and heavier menses, which suggests a hormonal imbalance, and the endometrial thickness is within normal limits. The most likely cause is endometrial hyperplasia, which is the overgrowth of the lining of the uterus due to an excess of estrogen relative to progesterone. Endometrial carcinoma is a possible complication of endometrial hyperplasia. Uterine adenomyosis and endometrial polyp may cause abnormal bleeding, but they are less likely in this case.
